I don't believe it was considered an argument for or against vaccinating children / teens for covid19, but simply an observation, among many (it's item 57 in a list of considerations) of what is likely to happen anyway, sooner or later, vaccination or not.3/

The way I read it is that infection during childhood is likely protective to those children themselves once they will be reinfected as adults. This is mainstream infectious disease epidemiology / immunology thinking and is the way we deal with ~200 endemic respiratory viruses.2/

The quote below from the JCVI minutes has enraged many people. It seems to have been widely understood as children getting infected by SARSCoV2 being protective for other adults. I believe this is a misunderstanding, as this interpretation doesn't make sense anyway.1/ https://t.co/1kyDYrNMv3

If we plot the current Case Fatality rate, the number of deaths per 100 diagnosed cases, we confirm that a high level of vaccination implies a low CFR, clearly around 0.5%.  5/ https://t.co/h4FpHAvB3Y

The number (2) corresponds to Hungary with a vaccination level just at 125 and a cumulative incidence of 4.3%. Numbers 3 and 4 correspond to Greece and Czech Republic. Finally, the 5th corresponds to Slovenia, which has also had a high incidence in the last six months (4.1%) 4/

The number (1) corresponds to Poland which has a low level of vaccination (103 doses per 100 inhabitants). Poland has had a high incidence accumulated in the last six months (4.2% of the population).  3/

We distributed countries into three groups: (1) countries with more than 126 doses of vaccine per 100 inhabitants, (2) countries with more than 100 doses and less than 126 per 100 inhabitants, and (3) countries with less than 100 doses of vaccine per 100 inhabitants.2/

I'm watching "Settlers" on Hulu, a story about a failed Martian colony.They've got spectacular engineering artifacts available, but the atmosphere generators have failed and it is down to two individuals.One who killed the parents of the other.

One group of kids raised up would be the end. The only following generation would be through violence. And this would continue for generations.At some later point, there might be enough people, but the social psychology at that time would be so very messed up.

Kids raised together from a young age tend to have strong blocks against pairing off with each other.This doesn't develop if they are raised apart, but the Adam & Eve scenario doesn't really allow for managing two isolated creches.
If there's just two people left, of appropriately matched biology, there's no "responsibility to have children". Those kids will only have each other to interact with.

It was a great privilege to work with many great colleagues from China and the UK, including some who are on twitter, @LucyvanDorp, @misac42, @RhysFarrer1. The project arose through a visit to the UK of a Chinese PhD student Hongbin Chen.8/https://t.co/sKkVOzONbT

The suggest that the ongoing replacement of ST239 by ST59 in China is not associated to higher AMR carriage or biofilm production. However, the increase in ST59 prevalence is concerning since it is linked to a higher potential for virulence, aided by carriage of the chp gene.7/

We experimentally validated the role of the chp gene in increasing the virulence potential of ST59 by creating Œîchp knockout mutants, confirming that ST59 can carry chp without a measurable impact on fitness.6/ https://t.co/kXqpTwwamE

ST59 isolates exhibit significantly higher virulence than ST239 isolates, despite carrying on average fewer putative virulence genes. We identified the chemotaxis inhibitory protein (chp) as a strong candidate for involvement in the increased virulence potential of ST59.5/

ST59 isolates carried fewer AMR genes than ST239 and showed no evidence of evolving towards higher AMR. Biofilm production was marginally higher in ST59, though this effect was not consistent across sub-lineages so is unlikely to be a sole driver of replacement.4/

We considered three non-mutually exclusive hypotheses for ST59 replacing ST239: a) higher antimicrobial resistance (AMR) of invading lineage; ability to colonise and persist in the environment through biofilm formation and c) higher virulence.3/

We used whole-genome sequencing data from the vanishing ( ST239) and replacing  lineage ST59 of isolates collected in Chinese hospitals between 1994 and 2016, and reconstructed the evolutionary history of each lineage.2/ https://t.co/3RCc5Wzcls

Methicillin-resistant Staph aureus (MRSA) is a major nosocomial pathogen. Since the 1950s, lineages have been replacing each other globally. We investigated a replacement over the last 20 years in China and show it might be largely driven by one gene.1/https://t.co/sKkVOzONbT

I've also re-phrased this rant into a more coherent comment on @PubPeer :https://t.co/HQ7Bz6FfWm...and would welcome opposing views to mine there as well, also under pseudonym.12/end

In summary, imo this is an over-interpretation of insufficient & inappropriate data for the problem. There are many possible explanations for the authors' observation and I doubt that it would generalize to other datasets & strain res approaches.11/

More importantly, the ASV data used by Rashidi et al generally does not even resolve strains (see above), but at best (sub-)species. So it is less appropriate here than what prior studies on the topic already provided.10/

Rashidi et al quite explicitly call out our study, but they misconstrue our approach. We explicitly profiled strain *populations*, not just single dominant strains. Indeed, the oral-gut overlap signal only emerges at that pop level.9/ https://t.co/j65Ua56GiN

So I don't think that the used dataset is appropriate to address the authors' question. In fact, the paper is a step back behind previous work (by us & others) that used strain-resolved metaG, not 16S, and multi-cohort designs.8/

3. Single cohort design.There are by now many studies with paired SA-ST seq available, both 16S & metaG. In 2019, we already used 310 subjects in 5 cohorts. Why use only one cohort here? Diff extraction in SA & ST, amp biases, etc.7/

2. Low pyroseq depths.The dataset used here has low seq depth, arguably too shallow to resolve low abundant taxa. Moreover, DADA2 to call ASVs can work on pyroseq, but is optimised towards Illumina data.6/

My main criticisms.1. ASVs ‚â† strains.ASVs are the highest resolution achievable w/ 16S, but almost always insufficient to resolve strains. For that, one needs high-resolution metaG (i.e., SNV calls or similar) or ofc isolate sequencing.5/
They observed only one ASV, classified as D. invisus, consistently in SA and ST (Figure 1). From this, they conclude that there is no colonization of oral microbes in the guts of healthy subjects.4/

Rashidi et al re-analysed 16S 454 pyroseq data of saliva (SA) and stool (ST) samples of 66 healthy volunteers, publ in 2015 (https://t.co/2gpC5cW0dp). They build Amplicon Sequence Variants (ASVs) which they claim "can be used to identify species, subspecies, and strains".3/

First off, I'm not unbiased here, as I previously co-led a study finding the exact opposite: extensive transmission of oral microbes to the gut (https://t.co/koW4cyRVR8). Our work is directly criticised here, but more about that later.2/

This study by Rashidi et al, published 10d ago in @PNASNews , concludes that there's "no evidence for colonization of oral bacteria in the distal gut of healthy adults".https://t.co/iQo5qcwkW2Imo, there are several problems with this work.üßµ1/

All together, the portal features: üîµ 72,909,456 variantsüîµ 34,659 genesüîµ 4,835 diseasesüîµ 33,781 studies, inc. 3,387 with fine-mappingüîµ 117,716 independent disease/trait-associated lociüîµ 1,410,101 trait-trait coloc testsüîµ 4,900 unique genes with an L2G score > 0.8 https://t.co/kdscHBkMuF
Since writing the manuscript, we have updated the Genetics Portal with additional data from @FinnGen_FI https://t.co/vyCmp5Ph6a

Other major features of the portal:‚úÖ Fine mapping of all published GWAS using either full summary statistics or linkage disequilibrium information only‚úÖ Colocalisation of GWAS and molecular trait QTLs as well as trait-trait GWAS
For a more in-depth explanation of the Locus-to-Gene (L2G) score in the Open Targets Genetics portal, see: https://t.co/Ebjz7AhfF5

The L2G score reflects the likelihood that a gene is causal for the trait in question, allowing genes at trait-associated loci to be ranked by the relative strength of their evidence. The target-disease association via GWAS evidence is  included in the Platform since version 4

A particularly exciting addition: the locus-to-gene (L2G) machine-learning scoring method, trained using GWAS loci where we have high confidence in the causal gene and a set of predictive features. Our GWAS Gold Standard repository is available at https://t.co/8BTNaOaRe8

Our comprehensive analysis pipeline formats, harmonises, and aggregates GWAS results, molecular QTLs & functional genomics data. Users can view the prioritised list of likely causal gene(s) at each GWAS-associated locus, and assess their potential as pharmaceutical drug targets

Read all about the latest updates to Open Targets Genetics in @NatureGenet! The Genetics Portal enables users to easily prioritise genes at disease and trait-associated loci and assess their potential as drug targets.üëâhttps://t.co/ezmewGxPzhOr keep scrolling for a recapüßµ https://t.co/GeFyVkMrUU

Oh, and do consider that we may have more experience or knowledge than our ‚Äúbehaviour‚Äù or career level may suggest. Some of us don‚Äôt care so much about careers, others are just exhausted, & underemployment of autistic people in terms of experience and skills is very much a thing.
If we‚Äôre lucky, with a lot of (often painful) experience, we can work with or around many of the things I mentioned, but it‚Äôs exhausting and comes at a (sometimes great) cost.
These things are not just ‚Äúincluding‚Äù or ‚Äúaccepting‚Äù - they require you to actively think about how you work and how you approach tasks, interact with, and task others.

If you are the line manager, if a task is completed well, don‚Äôt just heap more on. If you give us something we‚Äôll do it fully - this does not mean that you can automatically assume we still have more bandwidth(!).

Don‚Äôt ask questions you don‚Äôt want to hear the answer to. Really *listen* and be open to alternatives. Expect full, direct and thorough answers. When you give us a task, expect it to be completed - if there are special considerations or ‚Äúpolitics‚Äù to consider, tell us.

Your autistic peeps need you to be specific and provide context and reasoning. Avoid hidden agendas and fudged goals, or if you must fudge goals, be transparent about why. Avoid moving goal posts, but if they must move, explain why.

The challenge with ‚Äúinclusivity‚Äù of neurodivergence such as autism in the workplace is that it needs people not just to *act* differently (awareness of traits and culture), but to actually *work* differently to the way most work happens most of the time. (Bit of a üßµ)

Despite a small sample size, the findings of this #immunoinformatics study are important to our understanding of natural immunity & how it varies between individuals. The protein microarray provides a lot of resolution into this variation & I would love to see more use of it.

"With these first two sets of convalescent-phase sera provided by the Mayo Clinic and the CDC, we have shown that SARS-CoV-2-naive subjects have clearly measurable cross-reactive antibody to the whole N and S2 proteins and that this reactivity is limited to specific epitopes."

Interestingly, the authors note that "some SARS-CoV-2-naive individuals have substantial preexisting antibody to some epitopes of [N and S] proteins". This can be seen in the prev. heatmap but also in the Supplemental Data, esp. in S2 protein (purple=nat. immunity, orange=naive). https://t.co/oGD8lfiFf4

Each row on this heatmap is a different protein from the microarray, while each column is an individual (natural immunity "positives" on right; controls on left). There is a lot of variation between those with nat. immunity. Some may have more comprehensive antibody responses. https://t.co/TLuNYeuDsk

Cross-reactivity seems to happen because proteins in SARS-CoV-2 & SARS-CoV have high homology. This circos plot highlights (using magenta boxes) specific parts of the proteins (eg. S, N) that show strong antibody reactivity in those with natural immunity compared to uninfected. https://t.co/HxeufEGk6Z

COVID-19 patients with natural immunity showed high antibody reactivity (IgG, IgA, IgM) for the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2, but also notable is that there is significant cross-reactivity seen for the original SARS-CoV virus, particularly in the N protein. https://t.co/ueTeQ2aGaI

The authors have designed a very comprehensive protein microarray for #coronavirus, containing over 900 proteins. This includes the structural and accessory proteins of SARS-CoV-2 as well as proteins for other coronaviruses including SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV etc. https://t.co/sGZtU8llmw

A recent study that used a multi-protein microarray to explore in detail, antibody responses in those with natural immunity to COVID-19:Mapping SARS-CoV-2 Antibody Epitopes in COVID-19 Patients with a Multi-Coronavirus Protein Microarrayhttps://t.co/sx8Jd8H4DR #bioinformatics

Perhaps most importantly, however, they show the potential of integrating genomic surveillance and deep backward contact tracing at the local level - much remains to be learned about how SARS-CoV-2 moves through our populations at the person-to-person!

Our results complement data on the importance of international travel for SARS-CoV-2 spread with data at the person-to-person level. They also suggest that more stringent testing e.g. of return travellers or in settings with high transmission risk may contribute to containment.

... via a complex pattern of transmission in nightlife venues and the local community. The other cluster, by contrast, is driven by multiple independent introduction events also linked to return travel, with smaller-scale onward transmission in the community. https://t.co/ccJ6aYZKLd

Specifically, we investigate two large clusters of genetically related viral isolates and show that they are related to return travel; in one instance, a single (undetected) SARS-CoV-2-infected return traveller can be linked to >= 28 directly related downstream infections... https://t.co/aoPmtYbAkD

We show that the tracking of person-to-person SARS-CoV-2 transmission chains in the general population can be achieved even during "non-lockdown" periods with high incidences and full-blown community transmission, by integrating viral genome sequencing with deep contact tracing.

Very likely this list will grow much larger, so we created a repository to keep an updated list of methods that extract information from nanopore signal data: https://t.co/XD3OsUifYV  feel free to add new entries, we hope this will become a very useful resource! 5/6
most of this can be extracted using computational methods, many of which are included in this review 4/6 https://t.co/gQZKKanAiX

But the signal contains much more information that goes beyond purely sequencing: DNA and RNA modifications can be detected, polyA tails can be measured, the signal can be used for targeted sequencing, or it can be artificially altered to study RNA structures 3/6

Nanopore sequencing measures a current signal that corresponds to the native molecules. The primary application is sequencing - extracting the RNA or DNA sequence from the current signal 2/6 https://t.co/BixeIgZTMg

I'm very happy to share this review on computational methods that extract information from raw nanopore sequencing data https://t.co/kzB3NsWbqb Unlike other sequencing technologies, the @nanopore platform profiles nucleic acids directly, with many exciting applications 1/6 https://t.co/hekNWfPU5X

10/10 thanks to all colleagues who made this interdisciplinary collaboration a success through the challenging pandemic environment and peer review. Thanks to the funders for your support @tfri_research @OICR_news @CIHR_IRSC @NSERC_CRSNG !

9/10 expression levels of HOXA10-AS help identify high-risk patients with low-grade glioma, especially in the IDH-wildtype LGGs that often suffer from worse prognosis where HOXA10-AS-based analysis can lead to more precise risk predictions.

8/10 Our systematic analysis highlights potential of the non-coding cancer transcriptome for biomarker and therapy development, and exemplifies HOXA10-AS as a potent onco-lncRNA that regulates hallmark pathways in glioma (the mechanism still needs more work).

7/10 RNA-seq of HOXA10-AS o/e and k/d GBM cells showed transcriptome-wide deregulation, incl. proliferative, brain development and extracellular matrix processes. Some pathways also associated with HOXA10-AS expression in TCGA data, linking of our models to patient tumors.

6/10 Experiments with patient-derived GBM cells revealed HOXA10-AS as an onco-lncRNA: knockdown reduced proliferation while overexpression disrupted contact inhibition and Hippo signalling. o/e in xenografts led to worse mouse prognosis and increased invasion in brain organoids.

NanoSplicer can identify splice junction solely from the nanopore data without requiring annotations or matched short reads. Also, its performance is not affected by other mapped reads and is independent of read depth, enabling it to identify rare splice junctions. 3/3

NanoSplicer uses raw nanopore signals (squiggles) to improve splice junction identification.¬†Key idea is to identify, for each splice junction, which of the squiggles predicted from potential splice junction sequences best matches the observed junction squiggle. 2/3 https://t.co/qsTna5t40N

So being able to eat split chickpeas is A Huge Fucking Deal in my world.I may still need to limit my intake (another big factor) but it's still *incredibly exciting*.

Most annoyingly, I haven't been able to eat most legumes since. I was previously allergic to soy, but now that includes beans, lentils, chickpeas, peas, and even peanut butter in excess. Also I have yet to find a plant-based milk I can eat.

For about two years I was on an *incredibly* restrictive diet- basically fish, dairy, and potatoes, with grain only occasionally.I was able to reintroduce most things by mid-2016, but I still get occasional flare-ups.
I have post-infection IBS- basically, back in 2013 in Tanzania, I got amoebic dysentery, and the multiple rounds of antibiotics + the illness itself just nuked my intestinal flora, apparently.

I don't believe it is difficult to make a factual case for covid19 vaccination. There is extensive unassailable and striking evidence that they reduce deaths. Example below: Bulgaria and Romania have the lowest vaccination rates in the EU (~20% and ~30% respectively).5/ https://t.co/RCBZHaA0dD

It would seem ideal if everyone tried to stick to the data. Current covid19 vaccines are excellent at reducing morbidity/mortality upon infection, they reduce transmission to an extent, and have limited side-effects. Their benefit is maximal to those most at risk to covid19.4/

For example, if senior academics claim vaccines block viral transmission, and people learn about others having been infected post-vaccination, they will rightly conclude this was untrue, which will provide ammunition to those claiming vaccines don't reduce transmission at all.3/
Worse, I suspect the two groups actually synergistically contribute to sowing doubts about vaccines in the population.2/

I suspect those overhyping the efficacy of covid19 vaccines, in particularly against transmission, and dismissing any rare side-effect, may have done as much to fuel vaccine hesitancy than ideological vaccine opponents spouting bizarre nonsense (5G, syncitin-1 or whatnot).1/

The research team at Buchinger Wilhelmi, which I will proudly join in January, is already moving forward with a new study, larger and more precise, to understand effects of fasting on size, mass, composition and function of metabolic active tissues https://t.co/Uo0ng5yqoj

The reality is that protein sparing occurs during prolonged fasting in skeletal muscles. In this study, protein loss occured only in early fast but decreased as ketogenesis increased. Fat was the main fuel, not proteins. Ultimately, muscle function was maintained or even improved

Muscle and protein loss during long-term fasting has always been a concern. When fasting started to be used as a treatment for morbid obesity in the 1960s, patients generally received protein supplements. We know now that it was causing more harm than good.

Is muscle and protein loss relevant in long-term #fasting in healthy men? Impressive study from the Buchinger Wilhelmi clinics and @CNRS scientists showing that a 10¬†day fast does not negatively impact muscle function. https://t.co/cAigNoSAGC

They were checking for blood clots as he‚Äôs within the window post vax. It sounds like that‚Äôs ruled out. Husband picking him up now. He‚Äôll be totally dehydrated, tired and hungry. Hopefully he can keep some food down this morning. Hopefully the nebuliser was all that‚Äôs needed.

I‚Äôm told the wait will be long, I should go home (Saffron Walden is around half an hour away). When I get home I text the kid; he‚Äôs still on the chair in the entrance. He gets moved to a waiting area some time during the night. An hour ago he finally got a nebuliser.

Only as I ask about covid symptoms are we sent around the corner instead of being told to join the queue. After a brief discussion I am sent away as only the patient is allowed in (I am not an ‚Äúofficial carer‚Äù). The kid is sat on a chair; he looks very pale but gives a thumbs up.

An old man asks the security guard how much longer the wait is, his wife is exhausted. ‚ÄúWe can give her a wheelchair, would that help?‚Äù. Three ambulances at the door, unable to offload patients. The teams are looking after them in the vehicles and it looks like any other day.
Saffron Walden to Stansted for test. Back home. Then to Hertford out of hours GP. From there to to Addenbrookes in Cambridge. Long queue in front of A&E. Midnight.

@discretestates Yah I sometimes will allow them to submit outstanding assignments, particularly if life has gotten in their way, even when answers are posted. They are worth very little individually so it's really more about working through the problems.

@jasonaholliday That makes sense.  When I give extensions on weekly programming assignments, I also encourage students to start on the next assignment so that the delays don't stack up.  Usually I schedule some time near the end of the term for students to finish outstanding items.

@discretestates I give extensions within reason. For weekly assignments it's until I need to post the answers. No penalty. It takes me at least a week to grade term papers so more generous extensions for that are no big deal. I don't see a trend as far as quality for extension vs not

For me this would be a step towards producing a more productive black potato, but maybe not recurrently reproducing any specific hybrid.
Once I have my black and highly productive potato lines stabilized separately, I would only need to grow a single clone from each next to each other if I wanted to produce hybrid seed.

The ability to reliably produce a specific hybrid potato would also make it much simpler to reduce disease issues. Many diseases of concern in potatoes can't be passed along via seeds.Grow a whole crop from seed instead of last year's tubers, & you have no tuber-borne disease.

They're all quite small compared to commercial potatoes. This is fine by me. Each variety was grown from a tiny seed about a millimeter across. In their second year, the plants will be starting out with much more energy reserves and are expected to produce more and larger spuds.

The red was unexpected, but it tells me  the black/dark-purple is dominant over red (at least in my population) as there were only back varieties in the garden where the seeds came from.I don't know if I'll keep this one. Maybe.

The left black tubers have about 2 eyes each, compared to the right black tubers with about 9 eyes each. I'll keep both for now, as I want to have more diversity in my black spud patch, but I really like those smooth spuds.

The lower-left variety produced its tubers at the ends of long stolons. I grew the seedlings in pots sunk into the ground to allow easy harvest of any that grew like this, but I don't plan to continue with it.

The total production from my five seedling #DiploidPotatoes that survived the early beetle plague.The top three were from seed collected in my black potato patch. The lower two from seed in my large tuber patch. https://t.co/wSqyimb1Vx

(2) a certain "form over substance", bureaucratic feel - the EU empire strikes back? (3) latex submission gets processed through a workflow that messes up the equations. Not as bad as recent experiences on @AmerChemSociety journals, but still: WHY?!

Not-so-great: (1) took way too long to get the paper out, mostly due to back-and-forth on minor issues (CC-BY-NC vs CC-BY) that could have been sorted out later: one month before peer review even starts is too long;

Experience this far has been interesting and encouraging. Plus side: (1) responsive editorial staff who clearly cares about a new publishing model; (2) editorial revisions directly in overleaf: genius! publishers, take note; (3) they really enforce data and code sharing;
If you don't know it, the idea is free-to-authors-and-readers #openaccess publishing, with post-publication, fully transparent #peerreview

There are many more example but I just wanted to highlight a different perspective from a science/medical perspective. Maybe OWL is less useful for ecommerce use cases but it is filling a niche over here.

The Human Phenotype Ontology is a major standard for recording patient phenotypes and has been adopted by multiple rare disease orgs, clinical labs, major databases  + HPO software is driving genetic disease diagnoses. It relies on OWL reasoning https://t.co/CFUld67wnk

The Gene Ontology is one of the most widely used resources in biomedicine, mentioned or cited in about 15k publications/year. OWL reasoning is a crucial part of our infrastructure to validate the 45k terms + annotations, and to automate classification https://t.co/yGt2U13g4P

Most of @OBOFoundry is dependent on OWL reasoning, to automate the construction of hierarchies, to check ontologies for coherency. Every day Elk, HermiT, etc are invoked hundreds of times as github actions checking PRs on our many ontologies https://t.co/KnYC5SRUqY

Maintaining large ontologies (1000s+ terms) manually without use of reasoning is unsustainable. Decades of empirical experience with biological and medical terminologies going back to the 90s supports this. https://t.co/T0Rwgdmw3C

Why? While SKOS may work somewhat as a *distribution* format for those ontologies (some pros some cons - OWL for sure has limitations as an end-user datamodel, users prefer more graph-oriented), we absolutely need OWL reasoning to *build* the ontologies.

Bob suggests #SKOS for controlled vocabularies. But this wouldn't cut it for large scientific terminologies/ontologies such as @news4go @hp_ontology @uberanat #NCIThesaurus @SnomedCT and ontologies in @OBOFoundry

For sure, OWL has been over-used for datamodeling/schema tasks here too, where a closed-world formalism like #SHACL or @linkml_data (or even SQL DDL or JSON-Schema) is a better match. See https://t.co/Ij08hvhDgj for various inappropriate uses of the OWA

Some delayed thoughts on @bobdc's recent post "you probably don't need OWL". Interesting how our different backgrounds lead us to different perspectives, in the life sciences OWL seems more popular for ontologies 1/n https://t.co/LMC8pX176p

Sharing the resulting improved host-virus data for continued re-use is the primary goal of this project ‚Äî spearheaded by the efforts of @GlobalBiotic to create lightweight, open source resources for the community: e.g., https://t.co/a5yXihujWK7/ https://t.co/TvY26q7IMH

Building taxonomic & interaction intelligence opens the door for creating *probabilistic* knowledge graphs of host-virus ecology, which is what's needed to robustly predict viral spillover risks at finer levels than just "bats" or "rodents" (2/3rd of living mammal species)6/ https://t.co/2os6X9qo6a

We outline our taxonomy-centric approach in the @TheLancetPlanet article (https://t.co/DlzboU8cVl), emphasizing that the 'unlocking dark data' approach is inefficient vs. the 'created connected' publishing of @Pensoft.Digital knowledge needs to be the goal of all publishing.5/ https://t.co/mqatFMluUv

Our solution is two-part: (1) liberate #taxoknowledge from pubs w/ automated tools of @plazi_ch & connect it w/ current taxonomy of @mammaldiversity then (2) use the resulting taxonomic 'passkey' to search & unlock host-virus evidence in pubs for linking as digital knowledge.4/ https://t.co/yfJPpL6Gai

The problem is that existing host-virus data is often disconnected from evidence of either interaction (eg assay type, sample size) or taxonomy (eg voucher specimen, concept of species), which makes it hard to accurately model host-virus sharing w/ data collected long ago.3/ https://t.co/ntI9jSaOpr

The grant "Intelligently predicting viral spillover risks from bats and other wild mammals" is based from @asuSOLS with co-I @beckettws & team incl @Varsani_lab @taxonbytes @pguptanz w/ @GlobalBiotic & @plazi_ch: https://t.co/ZkujozaVUGGoal: Improve existing host-virus data2/ https://t.co/Soll1RU5EG

Glad to share that @ReederLab & I are leading a new NIH R21 project to liberate mammal-to-virus data from publications -- and then annotate them w/ supporting evidence to strengthen spillover risk modelsOur approach, newly outlined in @TheLancetPlanet https://t.co/DlzboU8cVl1/ https://t.co/2lSl501V16

This may offer some explanation regarding the people that report illness being in close quarters with recently vaccinated people. This also begs the question if Vax mRNA is being packaged, exhaled then inhaled in these exosomes.

Given the high dose of the injections (40 Trillion degradation resistant mRNAs), it is quite possible the vaccinated express more spike coated exosomes than naturally infected people. I would stay away from people fuming exosomes of SEB.

What is important to see here is that very low levels of SEB can create COVID pathologies: Dry Cough, Shortness of breath, Fluid in the lungs. So we need to know ASAP if vaccinated people are exhaling more spike coated exosomes than the naturally infected people.
An important paragraph of this paper was highlighted by a friend, tries to differentiate a natural exposure to a biological attack based exposure. https://t.co/6l7FOb1ywi
I don't know why SEB is in Spike. No other CV has this. This is a super-antigenic peptide that is often studied as a bioweapon. One of the best papers on SEB is below.https://t.co/ho5Yobe6uI

If its not localized to the injection site.. what do other exosomes do? They are often exhaled. Why is that a problem? Its not like they contain replication competent viral genomes. To understand this you need to know a dark secret about Spike called SEB. https://t.co/4Az6isWyf4

Why do we care is Spike is being packaged into exosomes? That implies it is then distributed all over the body and doesn't remain at the injection site. This confirms the Biodistribution data that de-platformed Bryam Bridle @WoodReporting

Precise, accurate, and inclusive language invites other marginalised genders to the table, where we can work in solidarity with women to improve our lot together. Women (cis and trans), non-binary and trans men have an awful lot more in common than divides us.

While sex obviously correlates with gender, female =/= woman and male =/= men. It does not erase women to acknowledge that with precise, accurate, and inclusive language (e.g. pregnant people as opposed to pregnant women).

Gender is a social construct comprising roles, behaviour, and identity. Gender is a spectrum. Most people strongly identify as either woman or man, but people also exist in the middle (non-binary) or do not identify with any gender at all (agender). https://t.co/p2m7ybhHAE

Sex is a biological trait classified as female, male, and intersex. Sex differences include sex hormone ratio, sex chromosome complement, and primary (genitals) and secondary (physical appearance) sex characteristics. There's huge variation in these within a sex too! https://t.co/lBIdipvAVN
This seems like a good time to run over the definitions of sex and gender. Luckily I have slides prepared.

What is perhaps more worrying is that it suggests the virus still has evolutionary paths to higher transmissibility open to it, and there are millions of Delta cases around the world without much sequencing coverage.

10-15% increase in growth rate would be annoying but not catastrophic for the coming months. Likely the reason we're seeing this in the UK is a combination of high case rates (more mutations happening) and high sequencing rates (see changing patterns quickly).
That is, landing 20 Delta infections in a place with only Alpha almost guarantees that it will go on to complete replacement, whereas 20 AY.4.2 landing in an existing Delta epidemic may well fizzle.

AY.4.2 hasn't yet spread much outside the UK, so could be a fluke (no biological advantage), but given that it's apparent advantage is modest, it needs to really get established somewhere to overcome stochasticity of small numbers.

And it has grown all over the place between mid-July (L) and now (R). AY.4 did a similar thing, but it was not displacing other Delta, and given that it hasn't spread through the world, likely just had some epidemiological luck. https://t.co/fyoyElx8ZV

Proportion of AY.4.2 (now on https://t.co/TBLIgGWt6U) has been steadily increasing in England, which is a pattern that is quite different from other AY lineages. Several of them rose when there was still Alpha to displace, but none has had a consistent advantage vs other Delta. https://t.co/mD5gQzKxgV

Amazing level of diversity; heavily enriched for resistance alleles. We find the 5 "borderline" resistant alleles listed by the WHO, and in addition several more, some quite rare. (Ah yes, the left hand panel is the same, but colouring shows frequency)  15/18

Here is what we see: In the right-hand panel: x axis= translated reference seq of the RRDR. Each coloured square is an amino-variant (product of non-syn SNP) seen in the cohort. Colouring shows what % of genomes  are resistant. Indels  shown under the x axis.   14/18 https://t.co/1mvQGP9hRQ

We focus on the 81bp rifampicin-resistance determining region (RRDR) in the rpoB gene. The WHO-endorsed Xpert MTB/RIF assay assumes any non-synonymous SNP in this region causes resistance to rifampicin, although as we discuss in the paper, the story is a little more complex 13/18

Mtb ought to be an easy species really - no recombination, low diversity, few mobile elements. Even so, we found roughly 1 SNP every 5bp (on average), and there were regions where every single base was a multiallelic SNP.  12/18

Martin built a @nextflowio pipeline to do this. In this paper we analyse the CRyPTIC cohort of ~15,000 Mtb genomes, adjudicating between cortex and samtools for each genome, and then joint genotyping. Total turnaround 26 hours (allowed 2000 simultaneous jobs, on a cluster)  11/18

You analyse each genome independently, combine and deduplicate all the variants found in all samples, make a single VCF of those sites, combining overlapping records, and then genotype all samples at all records.  10/18

One interesting fact is that a second important problem can also be framed as an adjudication problem: joint genotyping. When you have a cohort of genomeswhich you want to compare, you want a single multi-sample VCF with genotype calls at the same variants for all samples 9/18

Great thread contextualizing the 500k exome paper: https://t.co/aGwTz0BhUi
Feedback welcome! Lots of future work planned to extend these ideas. Try out the MGGP on mixed categorical and continuous data of your own: https://t.co/ijNfixXXQm

The MGGP gives a closed-form conditional posterior for specific groups. In regression, on GTEx data from 52 tissues & 1000 genes to predict ischemic time, the MGGP captures relationships within tissues, while sharing strength to reduce variance in the functions across all tissues https://t.co/crbnaQUzaS

The MGGP includes estimates of parameters that capture the similarity between categories in single variables, and also allows the user to specify those similarities in the prior. https://t.co/SshZ4pVtqS

Because the modification to the GP is entirely within the covariance function, standard methods for inference can be applied. We derive both MLE methods and fully Bayesian sampling that, in simulations, are quite accurate. https://t.co/IBJER2Fu1K
We then construct multi-group extensions of a variety of commonly-used covariance kernels. https://t.co/ICbe20y11g

Moving out of the Euclidean space in the definition of the GP covariance function, the MGGP encodes within- and between-variable dependencies in a positive definite covariance function defined on R^p√óC, where C is a finite set representing the group label. https://t.co/AJefZolc5y
We wanted to build an appropriate GP that combined the strengths of these models, but avoided explicit mixture models and static hierarchies. This proved challenging.https://t.co/DbACzqQCrr

The MGGP was motivated by our probabilistic contrastive PCA model, where we perform dimension reduction for case-control data, and our MOE-hierarchical Gaussian process, where we additively combine GPs across structured populations in a hierarchical model.https://t.co/JOZaeLm9jT
These data come up all the time: In EHR data, patient groups include: sex, race, comorbidities, and diagnoses; in genomic data, cellular groups include tissue-of-origin, batch number, and genotype.

Our goal here was to build a flexible model that uses all the data for inference so that small subgroups could be studied, but to ensure that the posterior would be specific to each arbitrary subgroup. https://t.co/fTNgzpfuKO
The MGGP jointly models continuous & categorical features; then, conditioning on specific categories, we obtain an explicit representation of the posterior specific for that population group.

If you recommended B, what if I tell you that Drug A on average extended lives by 5 years, much longer than the 1 year for Drug B? So solely focusing on P values but not on effect size is wrong. The same thing applies to selecting genes or pathways for further study.

1/3  Consider a cancer patient with two drugs.Drug A has been proven in clinical trials to be effective in extending lives over placebo with a P-value  = 0.001. Drug B has a P-value of 0.00001. Which one would you recommend? Think about this before reading on.

Removing the uninformative points will make predictions more accurate.  New case rates will no longer appear lower than they actually are on Mondays.  Starting today, these points will be removed from the plots I generate.  Comments?3/6

Let's look at these two plots.  The one of the left shows two weekends where the last value was repeated: Oct 8 and Oct 15.  The graph on the right removes these non-informative points.  Notice how the regression line (red) is much closer to the real data points.2/6 https://t.co/6hsLaicDf5

5/5 P-value measures statistical significance that depends on sample size and variance. Studies show that students sitting in the front row tend to have better grades. We can have very low P-values, but this is not an important factor for improving grades.

4/5 ShinyGO (https://t.co/e9hHjIIhBT) now offers the options to rank GO terms by fold-enriched. For the demo genes,  all top terms are related to DNA damage or cell cycle checkpoints. Large genesets like the cell cycle are ranked lower.  Thoughts? Suggestions? https://t.co/D4HmhYlxX5

3/5  Unlike P values, which can be heavily influenced by the size of gene-sets,  GO terms with the highest fold-enrichment are most drastically overrepresented. We should pay attention to these pathways first.

2/5 I think we should do the same with pathway/enrichment analysis.  In GO enrichment analysis, besides P values we can calculate fold-enrichment to measure effect size. DNA repair genes appeared 5 times more frequently than the background.

Ranking pathways by effect size, not statistical significance 1/5After numerous failed PCR confirmations, many now realized that the most important genes may not be the ones with the smallest P-value. After a P-value cutoff, we should rank genes by fold-change.

The burden of IBD on our patients can be very heavyWe won't always get it rightBut we can already to a lotLet's continue to raise our expectations and work to improve outcomes today and tomorrow https://t.co/bt8FQY3QOy

In the near future I hope we have a turbo-charged treatment paradigm that goes:1. stratify by RISK2. treat by BIOLOGY3. treat-to-target to achieve HOLISTIC REMISSION by4. monitoring symptoms, inflammation, QoL and other key PROsT2T plus precision medicine = GAME CHANGER https://t.co/aCg4uQ5Iyp

Treat-to-target worksImplementing STRIDE-II will make a big difference to patients livesWhen we ADD predictive capability we will truly enter the era of personalised medicine for inflammatory bowel disease https://t.co/uJyDY2aong

Treating patients by BIOLOGY is a big gap in our knowledgeWe are now in the multi-drug era for IBD with many more therapies using different mechanisms of action comingWe must aim to do better than trial and error when positioning therapies https://t.co/vlCec8d2cf

There are some factors associated with RISK in Crohn's disease‚Ä¢ smoking‚Ä¢ young age‚Ä¢ extensive disease‚Ä¢ peri-anal fistulising disease‚Ä¢ presence of deep ulcers at endoscopyBut we have not progressed this list in over 15 years https://t.co/bCZ1O0DDen

The two major gaps in our predictive ability at diagnosis are:1. Ability to stratify our patients by RISK (aggressive versus quiescent disease)2. Knowledge to treat patients by BIOLOGY (precision medicine) https://t.co/AaffWtmsyD

In some patients we have the existing toolkit to change thisBut it does require ‚Ä¢ early intervention‚Ä¢ maintenance drug therapy‚Ä¢ close monitoring following treat-to-targetThe rewards are great if we get this right https://t.co/4slgOg3PV7

The burden of IBD in many patients can be very marked‚Ä¢ physical symptoms‚Ä¢ psycho-social issues‚Ä¢ extra-intestinal manifestations‚Ä¢ complications relating to disease evolution https://t.co/PtNSZmtJgs

For many patients the disease will be complicatedSometimes we continue with drug therapy too long and these patients would be better served with a timely surgical interventionSurgery is a good option for many and not necessarily a treatment failure https://t.co/J6dZ0f5y4K
Approximately one third of patients with Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis will have a quiescent disease courseWe are at risk of over-treating these patients https://t.co/3nxV0rFMjA

Two patients can looks almost identical at diagnosis:‚Ä¢ patient A will respond brilliantly to therapy and never have a flare up‚Ä¢ patient B will not respond and will go on to have a complicated diseaseIt would be super helpful to know this at the start https://t.co/rT3xsjH0Db

There are several key points where we would like to be able to predict outcomes:‚Ä¢ who will get IBD (then we can intervene to prevent)‚Ä¢ who will response to what drug (personalised treatment)‚Ä¢ who will flare and when ‚Ä¢ who will have aggressive vs quiescent disease https://t.co/JGyNDNcjX2

@EdmundCrampin was very excited about the capabilities of bond graphs for biochemical modelling. We hope this paper can spread the word and promote their uptake.A huge thanks to the reviewers and @PLOSCompBiol editorial team for their feedback and input with publishing this

Working with researchers from @ABIaucklandacnz and the wider international team these approaches are being implemented in #CellML, and hopefully in the future this will allow integration with the large collection of #SBML models.

While many published models are valid, it can be difficult (and tedious) to construct and check models with traditional approaches, and many of the simplifying assumptions used in model creation may not hold under disease conditions or when models are combined for larger systems.

During his PhD Michael applied bond graphs to metabolic networks and signalling pathways, showing that modular components can be coupled without violating important thermodynamic and physical principles (e.g. allowing reversible reactions; conservation of mass and energy).

To summarise, the recent rise in the UK of AY.4.2 would be compatible with a transmissibility advantage of ~10%. As such, it feels worthwhile keeping an eye on it. Though, based on its genetic make-up, it is not a priori an obvious VoC candidate.8/

Y145H is fairly uncommon mutation (<0.02% outside AY.4.2) that pops up here and there and has been found in various genetic backgrounds. The mutation was first observed in March 2020. The two mutations have been found together in some strains dating back to April 2020.7/

A222V was found in the B.1.177 lineage that swept Europe in the summer of 2020, but careful follow-up analyses pointed to the lineage likely having no inherent transmissibility advantage and that its spread was caused by demographic processes.6/https://t.co/KJStFF2TV6

The spike Y145H and A222V mutations don't fall in the Receptor Binding Domain (RBD) and are not obvious candidates for immune escape, increased transmissibility or higher virulence. They are also not mutations found in other Variants of Concern (VoCs).5/https://t.co/2JCKILUSwD https://t.co/nRL395LkPg

The AY.4.2 lineage has attracted attention because it has risen in frequency in the UK over recent weeks, now representing ~7% of all sequenced strains. It remains exceptionally rare anywhere else (only 2 strains found in the US so far).4/ https://t.co/j4VENBKBsA

The most common of the Delta sub-lineages is AY.4, which now accounts for ~70% of all SARS-CoV-2 genomes sequenced worldwide. It has now given rise to two recognised sublineages, AY.4.1 and Y.4.2.3/ https://t.co/I4qLIucZ4x

Each lineage of SARS-CoV-2 accumulates on average ~2 mutations / month. Delta is no exception and has now been split into a 45 sublineages (AY.x.y), which are not particularly well resolved phylogenetically.2/ https://t.co/5A9aJSPZ2E

There is increasing twitter chatter about a new SARS-CoV-2 lineage termed AY.4.2, a descendant of the Delta (B.1.167.2) variant. It carries two characteristic mutations in the spike, Y145H and A222V. It is likely to be elevated to the rank of 'Variant under Investigation'. 1/
